sections.title: Purpose
sections.content: This document outlines the procedures for handling, testing, and disposing of biodegradable packaging materials in accordance with ASTM D6400 standards.

sections.title: Scope
sections.content: This SOP applies to all personnel involved in the production, testing, and disposal of biodegradable packaging materials.

sections.title: Responsibilities
sections.content:
- Production Manager: Ensure compliance with specifications
- Quality Control: Perform testing procedures
- Disposal Team: Properly handle waste materials
requirements: Production Manager must ensure compliance with specifications.
Quality Control must perform testing procedures.
Disposal Team must properly handle waste materials.

sections.title: Definitions
sections.content:
- Biodegradable: Materials that can be broken down by natural processes
- Compostable: Materials that biodegrade within a specified timeframe under composting conditions
- ASTM D6400: Standard Specification for Labeling of Plastics Designed to be Aerobically Composted in Municipal or Industrial Facilities

sections.title: Safety Requirements
sections.content: Personnel must wear appropriate PPE when handling materials. Note: This section intentionally lacks specific PPE requirements.
requirements: Personnel must wear appropriate PPE when handling materials.

sections.title: Materials Testing Procedures
sections.content:
6.1 All packaging must be tested according to ASTM D6400 standards
6.2 Testing shall include evaluation of biodegradation rate and environmental impact
6.3 Materials must achieve at least 90% biodegradation within 180 days
requirements: All packaging must be tested according to ASTM D6400 standards.
Testing shall include evaluation of biodegradation rate and environmental impact.
Materials must achieve at least 90% biodegradation within 180 days.

sections.title: Documentation
sections.content:
7.1 Maintain records of all testing procedures and results
7.2 Document compliance with IEEE 802.11 for wireless data transmission systems
7.3 Ensure all documentation is retained for at least 5 years
requirements: Maintain records of all testing procedures and results.
Document compliance with IEEE 802.11 for wireless data transmission systems.
Ensure all documentation is retained for at least 5 years.

sections.title: Disposal Procedures
sections.content:
8.1 Materials should be sent to industrial composting facilities
8.2 Partial degradation materials must be properly labeled
8.3 Non-compliant materials should be segregated and processed separately
requirements: Materials should be sent to industrial composting facilities.
Partial degradation materials must be properly labeled.
Non-compliant materials should be segregated and processed separately.

sections.title: Non-Compliance Actions
sections.content: If materials fail to meet specifications, production must be halted until issues are resolved.
requirements: If materials fail to meet specifications, production must be halted until issues are resolved.

sections.title: References
sections.content:
- ASTM D6400-23 Standard for compostable plastics
- 14 CFR Part 77 for structure height regulations
- IEEE 802.11 for wireless communication standards

relevant_clauses.title: Biodegradation
relevant_clauses.text: A level of biodegradation for the plastic products shall be established by tests under controlled conditions.

Ligno-cellulosic substrates are permitted to fulfill the requirements of 6.3 by demonstrating that they are “materials of natural origin” as defined in Specification D6868, and therefore assumed to be biodegradable by showing that over 95 % of their carbon comes from biobased resources, using Test Methods D6866. Any polymers or additives derived from biobased sources that are blended with ligno-cellulosic substrates shall separately demonstrate that they meet the requirements of 6.3 if they are more than 1 % of the dry weight of the end item.

relevant_clauses.title: No Adverse Impacts on Ability of Compost to Support Plant Growth
relevant_clauses.text: The tested materials shall not adversely impact on the ability of composts to support plant growth, when compared to composts derived from biowaste without any addition of tested products or reference materials. Additionally, the polymeric products or materials must not introduce unacceptable levels of regulated metals or hazardous substances into the environment, upon sample decomposition.

relevant_clauses.title: ISO Standard
relevant_clauses.text: ISO 17088 Specifications for Compostable Plastics

relevant_clauses.title: Disintegration During Composting
relevant_clauses.text: A plastic product or material will disintegrate during composting such that any remaining plastic residuals are not readily distinguishable from the other organic materials in the finished product. Additionally, the material or product must not be found in significant quantities during screening prior to final distribution of the compost.

relevant_clauses.title: Basic Requirements
relevant_clauses.text: In order to compost satisfactorily, a product or material must demonstrate each of the characteristics found in 5.1.1 – 5.1.3, and which are quantified in Section 6.

relevant_clauses.title: Specimen Preparation
relevant_clauses.text: Specimen preparation shall be in accordance with the specified test method.

relevant_clauses.title: Sampling
relevant_clauses.text: Sampling shall be conducted as indicated in the specified test method.

relevant_clauses.title: Hidden Node Problem and RTS/CLS mode
relevant_clauses.text: The IEEE 802.11 standard provides a mechanism to solve this problem called “Request-to-Send” and “Clear-to-Send” (RTS/CLS) scheme. The station wishing to send data first sends a Request-to-Send (RTS) frame to the intended destination station. Upon the reception of this frame, the receiving station sends a Clear-to-Send (CTS) frame. Both the RTS and CTS frames contain the duration of the communication that is going to take place.

relevant_clauses.title: Scope
relevant_clauses.text: The following safety hazards caveat pertains to the test methods portion of this standard: This standard does not purport to address all of the safety concerns, if any, associated with its use. It is the responsibility of the user of this standard to establish appropriate safety, health, and environmental practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.
A plastic or product demonstrates satisfactory terrestrial safety if it fulfills all the requirements in 6.4.1, 6.4.2, and 6.4.3:

relevant_clauses.title: U.S. Government Standard
relevant_clauses.text: 40 CFR Part 503.13 Standards for the Use or Disposal of Sewage Sludge
Plastic product test samples shall not be subjected to conditions designed to accelerate biodegradation, prior to testing in 6.3.

relevant_clauses.title: Marking and Labeling
relevant_clauses.text: Marking and labeling shall conform to national and local regulations.

relevant_clauses.title: Disintegration During Composting
relevant_clauses.text: A plastic product is considered to have demonstrated satisfactory disintegration if after twelve weeks (84 days) in a controlled composting test, no more than 10 % of its original dry weight remains after sieving on a 2.0-mm sieve. The test shall be carried out in accordance with ISO 16929 with a minimum vessel volume of 35 L, or ISO 20200 under thermophilic aerobic composting conditions.

relevant_clauses.title: Scope
relevant_clauses.text: The properties in this speciﬁcation are those required to determine if end items (including packaging), which use plastics and polymers as coatings or binders will compost satisfactorily, in large scale aerobic municipal or industrial composting facilities. Maximum throughput is a high priority to composters and the intermediate stages of plastic disintegration and biodegradation not be visible to the end user for aesthetic reasons.

relevant_clauses.title: Record of hearing
relevant_clauses.text: A change in the official transcript of a hearing may be made only if it involves an error of substance. Any recommendation to correct the transcript must be filed with the presiding officer within 5 days after the hearing closes. The presiding officer reviews each request for a correction to the extent he considers appropriate and shall make any revisions that he finds appropriate as a result of that review.

relevant_clauses.title: Detailed Requirements
relevant_clauses.text: In order to be identified as compostable in municipal or industrial aerobic facilities, products must pass the requirements of 6.2, 6.3, and 6.4 using the appropriate laboratory tests.

relevant_clauses.title: Biodegradation
relevant_clauses.text: Organic constituents present at levels between 1 to 10 % shall be tested individually for compliance to 6.3.1.

relevant_clauses.title: Recommendations by parties
relevant_clauses.text: Within 20 days after the mailing of the record of hearing by the official reporter, or as otherwise directed by the presiding officer, each party may submit to the presiding officer five copies of his recommendations for a final decision to be made by the Administrator.

relevant_clauses.title: Effective period of determinations
relevant_clauses.text: A determination issued under this subpart is effective 40 days after the date of issuance, unless a petition for discretionary review is received by the FAA within 30 days after issuance. The determination will not become final pending disposition of a petition for discretionary review.

relevant_clauses.title: Scope.
relevant_clauses.text: (a) This subpart requires each person proposing any kind of construction or alteration described in § 77.13(a) to give adequate notice to the Administrator. It specifies the locations and dimensions of the construction or alteration for which notice is required and prescribes the form and manner of the notice. It also requires supplemental notices 48 hours before the start and upon the completion of certain construction or alteration that was the subject of a notice under § 77.13(a).

relevant_clauses.title: Form and time of notice
relevant_clauses.text: You must submit this form at least 45 days before the start date of the proposed construction or alteration or the date an application for a construction permit is filed, whichever is earliest.

relevant_clauses.title: Construction or alteration requiring notice.
relevant_clauses.text: (a) Except as provided in § 77.15, each sponsor who proposes any of the following construction or alteration shall notify the Administra...

relevant_clauses.title: Applicability
relevant_clauses.text: The purpose of an aeronautical study is to determine whether the aeronautical effects of the specific proposal and, where appropriate, the cumulative impact resulting from the proposed construction or alteration when combined with other existing or proposed structures.

relevant_clauses.title: Parties to the hearing.
relevant_clauses.text: The presiding officer designates the following as parties to the hearing— (a) The proponent of the proposed construction or alteration. (b) Those persons whose activities would be substantially affected by the proposed construction or alteration.

relevant_clauses.title: Construction or alteration near the private residence of the President
relevant_clauses.text: This section applies to: (a) Any object of natural growth, terrain, or permanent or temporary construction or alteration, including appurtenances and equipment or materials used therein. (b) Any apparatus of a permanent or temporary character.

relevant_clauses.title: Using agency
relevant_clauses.text: For the purpose of this subpart, the using agency is the agency, organization or military command that established the requirements for the prohibited area.

relevant_clauses.title: Standards
relevant_clauses.text: The standards established in this part for determining obstructions to air navigation are used by the Administrator in: (1) Administering the Federal-aid Airport Program and the Surplus Airport Program; (2) Transferring property of the United States under section 16 of the Federal Airport Act; (3) Developing technical standards and guidance in the design and construction of airports; and (4) Imposing requirements for public notice of the construction or alteration of any structure where notice will promote air safety.

relevant_clauses.title: Priority classes in IEEE 802.11e
relevant_clauses.text: Each Access Category (AC) has its own parameters: CWmin (Minimum contention window), CWmax (Maximum Contention window), AIFS (Arbitrary Inter-frame Space which replaces DIFS of the conventional DCF), and TXOPLimit (Transmission Opportunity Limit). The different Access Categories have different priority assigned by setting the above mentioned parameters.

relevant_clauses.title: Kinds of objects affected.
relevant_clauses.text: This part applies to: (a) Any object of natural growth, terrain, or permanent or temporary construction or alteration, including equipment or materials used therein, and apparatus of a permanent or temporary character; and (b) Alteration of any permanent or temporary existing structure by a change in its height (including appurtenances), or lateral dimensions, including equipment or materials used therein.

relevant_clauses.title: Legal officer
relevant_clauses.text: The Chief Counsel designates a member of his staff to serve as legal officer at each hearing under this subpart. The legal officer may examine witnesses and assist and advise the presiding officer on questions of evidence or other legal questions arising during the hearing.

relevant_clauses.title: Conical surface
relevant_clauses.text: A surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal surface at a slope of 20 to 1 for a horizontal distance of 4,000 feet.

relevant_clauses.title: Horizontal surface
relevant_clauses.text: A horizontal plane 150 feet above the established airport elevation, the perimeter of which is constructed by swinging arcs of specified radii from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway of each airport and connecting the adjacent arcs by lines tangent to those arcs. The radius of each arc is: (1) 5,000 feet for all runways designated as utility or visual; (2) 10,000 feet for all other runways. The radius of the arc specified for each end of a runway will have the same arithmetical value. That value will be the highest determined for either end of the runway. When a 5,000-foot arc is encompassed by tangents connecting two adjacent 10,000-foot arcs, the 5,000-foot arc shall be disregarded on the construction of the perimeter of the horizontal surface.

compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP specifies that all packaging must be tested according to ASTM D6400 standards, which includes evaluation of biodegradation rate under controlled conditions, thus meeting the requirement of establishing biodegradation levels.

clause.title: Biodegradation
clause.text: A level of biodegradation for the plastic products shall be established by tests under controlled conditions.

missing_requirements: Demonstration that ligno-cellulosic substrates are materials of natural origin as per Specification D6868
Verification that over 95% of carbon comes from biobased resources using Test Methods D6866
Separate demonstration for polymers or additives derived from biobased sources if they are more than 1% of the dry weight
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not address the specific requirements for ligno-cellulosic substrates or the need for separate demonstration of biodegradability for biobased polymers or additives, which are critical for compliance with this clause.

clause.text: Ligno-cellulosic substrates are permitted to fulfill the requirements of 6.3 by demonstrating that they are “materials of natural origin” as defined in Specification D6868, and therefore assumed to be biodegradable by showing that over 95 % of their carbon comes from biobased resources, using Test Methods D6866. Any polymers or additives derived from biobased sources that are blended with ligno-cellulosic substrates shall separately demonstrate that they meet the requirements of 6.3 if they are more than 1 % of the dry weight of the end item.

missing_requirements: Assessment of adverse impacts on compost's ability to support plant growth
Verification that no unacceptable levels of regulated metals or hazardous substances are introduced
compliance_analysis.explanation: While the SOP includes evaluation of environmental impact, it does not explicitly ensure that the materials do not adversely affect compost's ability to support plant growth or introduce hazardous substances, which are essential for full compliance.

clause.title: No Adverse Impacts on Ability of Compost to Support Plant Growth
clause.text: The tested materials shall not adversely impact on the ability of composts to support plant growth, when compared to composts derived from biowaste without any addition of tested products or reference materials. Additionally, the polymeric products or materials must not introduce unacceptable levels of regulated metals or hazardous substances into the environment, upon sample decomposition.

missing_requirements: Compliance with ISO 17088 Specifications for Compostable Plastics
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not reference or ensure compliance with ISO 17088, which is necessary for meeting the requirements of this clause.

clause.title: ISO Standard
clause.text: ISO 17088 Specifications for Compostable Plastics

missing_requirements: Verification that plastic residuals are not readily distinguishable from other organic materials
Confirmation that materials are not found in significant quantities during screening
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP includes procedures for disposal and segregation of non-compliant materials but lacks specific measures to ensure that plastic residuals disintegrate to the required extent and are not found in significant quantities in the final compost product.

clause.title: Disintegration During Composting
clause.text: A plastic product or material will disintegrate during composting such that any remaining plastic residuals are not readily distinguishable from the other organic materials in the finished product. Additionally, the material or product must not be found in significant quantities during screening prior to final distribution of the compost.

missing_requirements: Specific characteristics from 5.1.1 – 5.1.3 are not explicitly mentioned
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP mentions testing according to ASTM D6400 standards and achieving 90% biodegradation within 180 days, which partially addresses the basic requirements. However, it does not explicitly list or ensure compliance with each characteristic found in 5.1.1 – 5.1.3 as required by the clause.

clause.title: Basic Requirements
clause.text: In order to compost satisfactorily, a product or material must demonstrate each of the characteristics found in 5.1.1 – 5.1.3, and which are quantified in Section 6.

missing_requirements: Specimen preparation in accordance with the specified test method is not mentioned
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not mention any procedures or guidelines for specimen preparation as required by the clause. This is a critical step in ensuring accurate testing results.

clause.title: Specimen Preparation
clause.text: Specimen preparation shall be in accordance with the specified test method.

missing_requirements: Sampling procedures as indicated in the specified test method are not mentioned
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP lacks any mention of sampling procedures, which are essential for ensuring that the materials tested are representative and that the results are valid.

clause.title: Sampling
clause.text: Sampling shall be conducted as indicated in the specified test method.

missing_requirements: No mention of RTS/CTS mechanism for solving the hidden node problem
compliance_analysis.explanation: While the SOP references IEEE 802.11 for wireless data transmission, it does not address the RTS/CTS mechanism for solving the hidden node problem, which is a specific requirement of the clause.

clause.title: Hidden Node Problem and RTS/CLS mode
clause.text: The IEEE 802.11 standard provides a mechanism to solve this problem called “Request-to-Send” and “Clear-to-Send” (RTS/CLS) scheme. The station wishing to send data first sends a Request-to-Send (RTS) frame to the intended destination station. Upon the reception of this frame, the receiving station sends a Clear-to-Send (CTS) frame. Both the RTS and CTS frames contain the duration of the communication that is going to take place.

missing_requirements: Specific safety, health, and environmental practices are not detailed
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP includes a general safety requirement for PPE but lacks detailed safety, health, and environmental practices as required by the clause. The responsibility to establish these practices is noted, but specifics are not provided.

clause.title: Scope
clause.text: The following safety hazards caveat pertains to the test methods portion of this standard: This standard does not purport to address all of the safety concerns, if any, associated with its use. It is the responsibility of the user of this standard to establish appropriate safety, health, and environmental practices and determine the applicability of regulatory limitations prior to use.

compliance_analysis.addressed_by: Section 6.2 mentions testing procedures but lacks specific details.
missing_requirements: SOP does not mention requirements 6.4.1, 6.4.2, and 6.4.3 for terrestrial safety.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not address the specific requirements outlined in clause 6.4 for demonstrating satisfactory terrestrial safety. Without these details, the SOP cannot ensure compliance with the necessary safety standards.

clause.text: A plastic or product demonstrates satisfactory terrestrial safety if it fulfills all the requirements in 6.4.1, 6.4.2, and 6.4.3:

missing_requirements: The SOP does not reference or comply with 40 CFR Part 503.13 standards for the use or disposal of sewage sludge.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP lacks any mention of compliance with 40 CFR Part 503.13, which is necessary for ensuring proper disposal standards are met. This could lead to regulatory issues if sewage sludge is involved in the disposal process.

clause.title: U.S. Government Standard
clause.text: 40 CFR Part 503.13 Standards for the Use or Disposal of Sewage Sludge

compliance_analysis.addressed_by: Section 6.1 mentions testing according to ASTM D6400 standards.
missing_requirements: The SOP does not explicitly state that test samples shall not be subjected to conditions designed to accelerate biodegradation.
compliance_analysis.explanation: While the SOP requires testing according to ASTM D6400 standards, it does not explicitly prohibit the acceleration of biodegradation prior to testing, which is a requirement in clause 6.3.4.

clause.text: Plastic product test samples shall not be subjected to conditions designed to accelerate biodegradation, prior to testing in 6.3.

compliance_analysis.addressed_by: Section 8.2 mentions labeling of partial degradation materials.
missing_requirements: The SOP does not ensure that marking and labeling conform to national and local regulations.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP mentions labeling but does not ensure compliance with national and local regulations, which is critical for legal and safety reasons.

clause.title: Marking and Labeling
clause.text: Marking and labeling shall conform to national and local regulations.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not specify testing in accordance with ISO 16929 or ISO 20200.
The SOP does not mention the requirement for no more than 10% of original dry weight remaining after sieving.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP lacks specific testing procedures required by clause 6.2, such as the use of ISO standards and the disintegration criteria. This omission could result in non-compliance with composting disintegration standards.

clause.title: Disintegration During Composting
clause.text: A plastic product is considered to have demonstrated satisfactory disintegration if after twelve weeks (84 days) in a controlled composting test, no more than 10 % of its original dry weight remains after sieving on a 2.0-mm sieve. The test shall be carried out in accordance with ISO 16929 with a minimum vessel volume of 35 L, or ISO 20200 under thermophilic aerobic composting conditions.

missing_requirements: Intermediate stages of plastic disintegration and biodegradation not be visible to the end user for aesthetic reasons
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP addresses the requirement for testing biodegradable packaging materials according to ASTM D6400 standards and specifies disposal in industrial composting facilities. However, it does not explicitly address the requirement that intermediate stages of plastic disintegration and biodegradation should not be visible to the end user for aesthetic reasons.

clause.title: Scope
clause.text: The properties in this speciﬁcation are those required to determine if end items (including packaging), which use plastics and polymers as coatings or binders will compost satisfactorily, in large scale aerobic municipal or industrial composting facilities. Maximum throughput is a high priority to composters and the intermediate stages of plastic disintegration and biodegradation not be visible to the end user for aesthetic reasons.

missing_requirements: Procedure for changing the official transcript of a hearing
Filing recommendations with the presiding officer within 5 days
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not address any procedures related to hearings or transcripts, as it is focused on biodegradable packaging materials. This clause is not relevant to the SOP's scope.

clause.title: Record of hearing
clause.text: A change in the official transcript of a hearing may be made only if it involves an error of substance. Any recommendation to correct the transcript must be filed with the presiding officer within 5 days after the hearing closes. The presiding officer reviews each request for a correction to the extent he considers appropriate and shall make any revisions that he finds appropriate as a result of that review.

missing_requirements: Passing requirements of 6.2, 6.3, and 6.4 using appropriate laboratory tests
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP mentions testing according to ASTM D6400 standards but does not specify that products must pass the requirements of sections 6.2, 6.3, and 6.4 using appropriate laboratory tests. This is a critical requirement for identifying products as compostable.

clause.title: Detailed Requirements
clause.text: In order to be identified as compostable in municipal or industrial aerobic facilities, products must pass the requirements of 6.2, 6.3, and 6.4 using the appropriate laboratory tests.

missing_requirements: Testing organic constituents present at levels between 1 to 10% individually for compliance
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not mention testing organic constituents present at levels between 1 to 10% individually for compliance, which is a specific requirement under ASTM D6400 section 6.3.1.1.

clause.title: Biodegradation
clause.text: Organic constituents present at levels between 1 to 10 % shall be tested individually for compliance to 6.3.1.

missing_requirements: Submission of recommendations for a final decision within 20 days after mailing of the record of hearing
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not address any procedures related to hearings or recommendations for final decisions, as it is focused on biodegradable packaging materials. This clause is not relevant to the SOP's scope.

clause.title: Recommendations by parties
clause.text: Within 20 days after the mailing of the record of hearing by the official reporter, or as otherwise directed by the presiding officer, each party may submit to the presiding officer five copies of his recommendations for a final decision to be made by the Administrator.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not address the effective period of determinations as outlined in § 77.33.
There is no mention of a petition for discretionary review or the 40-day effective period.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not include any procedures or references related to the effective period of determinations or the process for discretionary review as required by § 77.33. This could lead to non-compliance with regulatory timelines.

clause.title: Effective period of determinations
clause.text: A determination issued under this subpart is effective 40 days after the date of issuance, unless a petition for discretionary review is received by the FAA within 30 days after issuance. The determination will not become final pending disposition of a petition for discretionary review.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not require notice to the Administrator for construction or alteration as described in § 77.11.
There is no specification of locations and dimensions or the form and manner of notice.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP lacks any procedures for notifying the Administrator about construction or alteration activities, which is a critical requirement under § 77.11. This omission could result in significant regulatory non-compliance.

clause.title: Scope.
clause.text: (a) This subpart requires each person proposing any kind of construction or alteration described in § 77.13(a) to give adequate notice to the Administrator. It specifies the locations and dimensions of the construction or alteration for which notice is required and prescribes the form and manner of the notice. It also requires supplemental notices 48 hours before the start and upon the completion of certain construction or alteration that was the subject of a notice under § 77.13(a).

missing_requirements: The SOP does not include a requirement to submit a notice form at least 45 days before construction or alteration as required by § 77.7.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP fails to address the timing and submission of notice forms for construction or alteration, which is a mandatory requirement under § 77.7. This could lead to unauthorized construction activities.

clause.title: Form and time of notice
clause.text: You must submit this form at least 45 days before the start date of the proposed construction or alteration or the date an application for a construction permit is filed, whichever is earliest.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not include any notification procedures for construction or alteration as required by § 77.13.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not mention any requirement for notifying the Administrator about construction or alteration activities, which is essential under § 77.13. This could result in regulatory violations.

clause.title: Construction or alteration requiring notice.
clause.text: (a) Except as provided in § 77.15, each sponsor who proposes any of the following construction or alteration shall notify the Administra...

missing_requirements: The SOP does not address the need for an aeronautical study to assess aeronautical effects as required by § 77.25.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not consider the aeronautical impact of construction or alteration activities, which is necessary under § 77.25. This could lead to oversight of potential aeronautical hazards.

clause.title: Applicability
clause.text: The purpose of an aeronautical study is to determine whether the aeronautical effects of the specific proposal and, where appropriate, the cumulative impact resulting from the proposed construction or alteration when combined with other existing or proposed structures.

missing_requirements: Designation of parties to the hearing as per § 77.51
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not address any procedures related to hearings or the designation of parties as required by § 77.51. This clause is not relevant to the SOP's focus on biodegradable packaging materials.

clause.title: Parties to the hearing.
clause.text: The presiding officer designates the following as parties to the hearing— (a) The proponent of the proposed construction or alteration. (b) Those persons whose activities would be substantially affected by the proposed construction or alteration.

missing_requirements: Consideration of construction or alteration near the private residence of the President
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not involve any construction or alteration activities near the private residence of the President. This clause is not applicable to the SOP's scope.

clause.title: Construction or alteration near the private residence of the President
clause.text: This section applies to: (a) Any object of natural growth, terrain, or permanent or temporary construction or alteration, including appurtenances and equipment or materials used therein. (b) Any apparatus of a permanent or temporary character.

missing_requirements: Identification of the using agency as per § 73.85
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not establish any requirements for a prohibited area or identify a using agency. This clause is not relevant to the SOP's focus on biodegradable packaging materials.

clause.title: Using agency
clause.text: For the purpose of this subpart, the using agency is the agency, organization or military command that established the requirements for the prohibited area.

missing_requirements: Standards for determining obstructions to air navigation
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP does not involve any standards related to air navigation or airport construction. This clause is not applicable to the SOP's scope.

clause.title: Standards
clause.text: The standards established in this part for determining obstructions to air navigation are used by the Administrator in: (1) Administering the Federal-aid Airport Program and the Surplus Airport Program; (2) Transferring property of the United States under section 16 of the Federal Airport Act; (3) Developing technical standards and guidance in the design and construction of airports; and (4) Imposing requirements for public notice of the construction or alteration of any structure where notice will promote air safety.

missing_requirements: Specific parameters for Access Categories (CWmin, CWmax, AIFS, TXOPLimit)
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP mentions compliance with IEEE 802.11 for wireless data transmission systems in Section 7.2, but it does not specify the parameters for Access Categories as required by IEEE 802.11e. This could impact the prioritization of data transmission, which is important for maintaining compliance with the standard.

clause.title: Priority classes in IEEE 802.11e
clause.text: Each Access Category (AC) has its own parameters: CWmin (Minimum contention window), CWmax (Maximum Contention window), AIFS (Arbitrary Inter-frame Space which replaces DIFS of the conventional DCF), and TXOPLimit (Transmission Opportunity Limit). The different Access Categories have different priority assigned by setting the above mentioned parameters.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not address any requirements related to objects of natural growth, terrain, or construction/alteration of structures as specified in § 77.5.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP focuses on biodegradable packaging materials and does not involve any construction or alteration of structures, which is the focus of § 77.5. Therefore, it does not address this clause.

clause.title: Kinds of objects affected.
clause.text: This part applies to: (a) Any object of natural growth, terrain, or permanent or temporary construction or alteration, including equipment or materials used therein, and apparatus of a permanent or temporary character; and (b) Alteration of any permanent or temporary existing structure by a change in its height (including appurtenances), or lateral dimensions, including equipment or materials used therein.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not mention any legal officer or procedures related to hearings as specified in § 77.47.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP is concerned with handling, testing, and disposing of biodegradable packaging materials and does not involve legal proceedings or hearings, which are the focus of § 77.47.

clause.title: Legal officer
clause.text: The Chief Counsel designates a member of his staff to serve as legal officer at each hearing under this subpart. The legal officer may examine witnesses and assist and advise the presiding officer on questions of evidence or other legal questions arising during the hearing.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not address any requirements related to conical surfaces or their specifications as outlined in § 77.27(b).
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP is not related to aviation or airport structures, which are the focus of § 77.27(b) regarding conical surfaces.

clause.title: Conical surface
clause.text: A surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal surface at a slope of 20 to 1 for a horizontal distance of 4,000 feet.

missing_requirements: The SOP does not address any requirements related to horizontal surfaces or their specifications as outlined in § 77.25(a).
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP is not related to aviation or airport structures, which are the focus of § 77.25(a) regarding horizontal surfaces.

clause.title: Horizontal surface
clause.text: A horizontal plane 150 feet above the established airport elevation, the perimeter of which is constructed by swinging arcs of specified radii from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway of each airport and connecting the adjacent arcs by lines tangent to those arcs. The radius of each arc is: (1) 5,000 feet for all runways designated as utility or visual; (2) 10,000 feet for all other runways. The radius of the arc specified for each end of a runway will have the same arithmetical value. That value will be the highest determined for either end of the runway. When a 5,000-foot arc is encompassed by tangents connecting two adjacent 10,000-foot arcs, the 5,000-foot arc shall be disregarded on the construction of the perimeter of the horizontal surface.

recommendations.summary: The SOP requires comprehensive updates to address compliance gaps across multiple regulatory standards, particularly focusing on ASTM D6400 and 14 CFR Part 77. High-priority changes include ensuring proper testing and documentation for compostability, safety, and environmental impact, as well as establishing procedures for construction notifications and hearings. Medium and low-priority changes involve refining testing protocols, safety practices, and legal procedures.

improvements.change: Include a section to demonstrate that ligno-cellulosic substrates are materials of natural origin as per Specification D6868, and verify that over 95% of carbon comes from biobased resources using Test Methods D6866.
improvements.rationale: This change ensures compliance with ASTM D6400 Section 6.3.3, which is critical for verifying the biodegradability of materials.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Conduct tests using D6866 and document results in the SOP to verify compliance.

improvements.change: Add procedures to assess the impact of tested materials on compost's ability to support plant growth and verify that no unacceptable levels of regulated metals or hazardous substances are introduced.
improvements.rationale: Ensures compliance with ASTM D6400 Section 5.1.3, protecting environmental and human health.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Incorporate testing protocols for plant growth and metal/hazardous substance analysis.

improvements.change: Incorporate compliance with ISO 17088 Specifications for Compostable Plastics.
improvements.rationale: Aligns the SOP with international standards for compostable plastics, enhancing credibility and market acceptance.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Review ISO 17088 requirements and integrate relevant testing and documentation procedures.

improvements.change: Ensure verification that plastic residuals are not readily distinguishable from other organic materials and confirm that materials are not found in significant quantities during screening.
improvements.rationale: Addresses ASTM D6400 Section 5.1.1 requirements for compost quality and environmental safety.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Implement visual and quantitative assessments during compost screening processes.

improvements.change: Detail specimen preparation in accordance with the specified test method.
improvements.rationale: Ensures accurate and reliable test results, complying with ASTM D6400 Section 8.1.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Specify preparation steps and conditions in the SOP, referencing the relevant test methods.

improvements.change: Include sampling procedures as indicated in the specified test method.
improvements.rationale: Ensures consistency and reliability in testing, addressing ASTM D6400 Section 7.1.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Define sampling methods and conditions in the SOP, ensuring alignment with test method requirements.

improvements.change: Add a section to ensure marking and labeling conform to national and local regulations.
improvements.rationale: Compliance with ASTM D6400 Section 9.1 is essential for legal and market acceptance.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Review relevant regulations and update labeling practices accordingly.

improvements.change: Specify testing in accordance with ISO 16929 or ISO 20200, and ensure no more than 10% of original dry weight remains after sieving.
improvements.rationale: Critical for demonstrating compostability as per ASTM D6400 Section 6.2.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Integrate ISO testing protocols and document results in the SOP.

improvements.change: Establish procedures for notifying the Administrator of construction or alteration as described in § 77.11.
improvements.rationale: Ensures compliance with 14 CFR Part 77, facilitating safe and legal construction practices.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Develop a notification process and include it in the SOP, specifying required information and timelines.

improvements.change: Include a requirement to submit a notice form at least 45 days before construction or alteration as required by § 77.7.
improvements.rationale: Ensures timely compliance with regulatory requirements, preventing legal and operational issues.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Create a timeline and checklist for submission of notices, ensuring adherence to the 45-day requirement.
